Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Identification of disease resistance traits to improve the productivity and sustainability of soybean cultivation
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to improve the productivity and environmental sustainability of soybean cultivation. Soybean is the most widely grown crop in the United States with nearly 90 million acres under cultivation. Soybean is a key part of the food system and generates $22 billion in export revenue each year. One of the greatest threats to soybean production is the fungal pathogen known as Asian Soybean Rust. Current commercial soybean varieties have no resistance to this pathogen and over $2 billion is spent annually on fungicides to control this disease. While soybean is highly susceptible to this disease, many wild plant species have natural resistance to this pathogen. This project seeks to identify the naturally occurring mechanisms of disease resistance in wild plant species that can be used to develop disease-resistant soybean varieties. Adoption of these varieties is expected to bring more than $4 billion in value to the soybean industry while improving productivity and reducing fungicide use.

The intellectual merit of this SBIR Phase I project is to identify plant immune receptor proteins that confer disease resistance to Asian Soybean Rust, which is caused by the fungal pathogen Phakopsora pachyrhizi. A key determinant of whether or not a plant is resistant to a particular pathogen is whether the plant has an appropriate immune receptor protein capable of recognizing the presence of the invading pathogen. Once activated, plant immune receptors trigger plant defense responses that typically result in immunity. This project will use reverse genetic and biochemical approaches to identify plant immune receptor proteins that confer resistance to Asian Soybean Rust. Preliminary work identified several molecules from Phakopsora that elicit an immune response in non-host plant species. The goal is to identify the cognate immune receptors and test them for sufficiency to enable immune activation in response to Asian Soybean Rust elicitor molecules. This research will enable future work to the development soybean varieties with resistance to Asian Soybean Rust.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Improving the efficiency and productivity of agricultural systems is essential to provide enough food for a growing global population while minimizing the environmental impacts of agriculture. Plant pathogens; including fungi, bacteria and viruses; are a constant threat to productivity and any yield loss they inflict represents wasted land, fertilizer, labor and other inputs. Chemical controls, such as fungicides, can help protect plants from disease but increase the cost of production and pose risks to the health of workers, consumers and the environment. Developing crop varieties that are immune to disease is a safe, economical and environmentally friendly way to protect plant health. Wild plant species that are naturally immune to a particular pathogen can be used as sources of disease resistance traits to develop new disease-resistant crop varieties. In this project we investigated genetic mechanisms of resistance against the disease Asian Soybean Rust. This disease is caused by the fungal pathogen Phakopsora pachyrhizi and inflicts more than $4 billion in damage to the soybean industry each year.

During this project we identified a gene that mediates resistance to Asian Soybean Rust. This gene codes for an immune receptor which recognizes a specific elicitor protein from the pathogen. Our gene discovery methodology is faster and less labor-intensive than traditional discovery methods and does not require crosses or genetic mapping. We identified the elicitor protein and found that it is conserved across diverse pathogen isolates. Upon invasion of the plant, the immune receptor recognizes the protein elicitor from the pathogen and activates endogenous plant defense responses which suppress pathogen growth and sporulation. Cultivated soybean varieties contain hundreds of plant immune receptor genes but lack the gene we identified and are susceptible to Asian Soybean Rust. Expression of this gene in soybean is expected to confer broad and durable resistance to this pathogen. This will improve soybean yield, reduce the need for chemical fungicides, and improve the environmental sustainability of soybean production.
